sn45.2:4.2: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Sakyans, where they have a town called Nagaraka.
sn45.2:4.3: Then Venerable Ānanda went up to the Buddha,
sn45.2:4.4: bowed, sat down to one side,
sn45.2:4.6: “Sir, good friends, companions, and associates are half the spiritual life.”
sn45.2:5.2: Good friends, companions, and associates are the whole of the spiritual life.
sn45.2:5.4: A mendicant with good friends, companions, and associates can expect to
sn45.2:5.5: develop and cultivate the noble eightfold path.
sn45.2:6.1: And how does a mendicant with good friends develop and cultivate the noble eightfold path?
sn45.2:6.2: It’s when a mendicant develops right view, which relies on seclusion, fading away, and cessation, and ripens as letting go.
sn45.2:6.9: right samādhi, which relies on seclusion, fading away, and cessation, and ripens as letting go.
sn45.2:6.10: That’s how a mendicant with good friends develops and cultivates the noble eightfold path.
sn45.2:7.1: And here’s another way to understand how good friends are the whole of the spiritual life.
sn45.2:7.3: For, by relying on me as a good friend, sentient beings who are liable to rebirth, old age, and death, to sorrow, crying, pain, sadness, and distress are freed from all these things.
sn45.2:7.7: This is another way to understand how good friends are the whole of the spiritual life.”
